@polotek @AlanaSemuels OK, I give up. Supply and demand is not jargon. It’s literally the very first thing you learn about economics. Page one.
@GuyDealership Micro ain't necessarily macro. That's why they have different names.

@polotek @AlanaSemuels Last month I rented a new office. I tried very hard to get the price down. They wouldn't budge. They had other people looking, I had few other options. Supply and demand against me. I moaned, and paid the sticker price.
@polotek @AlanaSemuels It's really nothing like that at all. That's racism. We're talking about supply and demand. Draw the curves. Supply down, demand up >> higher prices. It's not hard.

@polotek @AlanaSemuels Where did I say was ever happy to pay more for something than I would like? But that doesn't mean I was gouged. It just means the balance of supply and demand was not in my favour. Right now, used car prices are dropping 1-2% per week. Doesn't mean buyers are stiffing dealers.

@polotek @AlanaSemuels 2. How else does he allocate his limited supply among competing customers? Lottery? Drawing straws? Plus if he does not charge more, how can he cover his fixed costs (rent, etc) if he has many fewer cars to sell? Do you own a business?

@polotek @AlanaSemuels 1. Paying more than you would like to have paid is not necessarily gouging. A monopolist charging whatever he likes is gouging. A car dealer in a competitive market charging more because he has very little inventory and high demand is not gouging.

@carney There's no dispute here. An uptick in the m/m from 0.2% to 0.4% is *nowhere near* statistically significant. The standard deviation in the m/m changes since the data begin is 0.3%. To be significant, the Aug print would have had to be ~0.8% or more.

@carney You and Joe Biden are the only two people who would define a change in the one-month change in a wildly volatile variable as acceleration/decleration. I've already explained to you what happened in Aug, and why it will reverse. Here's a chart of core PPI inflation. Accelerating? https://t.co/SMEI5TdK7D
@Plethorus1 @DionRabouin @TheStalwart True on both counts, up to a point.
If you don’t know the difference between an increase and an acceleration, please unfollow me. For the sake of my sanity.

@carney Also, for the record, an acceleration is an increase in the rate of change. Not merely an increase. An index can be decelerating while still rising, which is exactly what is happening in the core PPI.
@carney ... I really hope you don't start talking about deflation.

@carney ...and the PPI therefore records a temporary increase in margins, which is part of the services component. This likely will happen again in Sep, given the further drop in gas prices, and then it will reverse, in full, over the next few months. At which points...

@carney 1. No, that's a one-month increase in an erratic series. Most of the increase in PPI services in Aug was due to the way falling gas prices are treated in the PPI. When wholesale gas prices fall, input prices for gas stations drop. Retail prices move with a lag...
@DionRabouin @TheStalwart Me too, but we're members of a small club!

@carney ??? Services PPI is not accelerating, quite the opposite. y/y was 6.6% in Aug, fifth straight drop from the 9.4% peak in March. 3m/3m now 3.9% annualized, was 10.8% in March. The m/m had a bit of a boost from a technical quirk in Aug (maybe Sep too) but will fully reverse in Q4.
No one cares about the PPI any more. But for the record, the underlying trends in producer inflation are falling quite fast.

4. Bottom line: Not much in the report for the Fed to hate, but still some way from where they want to be. They still need to keep hiking, but these data make the case for 50bp this month a bit stronger. All depends now on the CPI in a couple weeks.
3. Also, I don't buy the downshift in wage gains to just 0.3% in Aug; could easily be the reappearance of a calendar quirk which was swamped during the pandemic by all the other craziness.

2. Unemployment rose in Aug because of a big jump in participation, but this won't happen every month. Job gains at 300K are *more likely* to push the rate down rather than up, though anyone who claims to *know* what's going to happen to participation is delusional.

1. Payroll growth is moderating, even allowing for the (decent) chance Aug is revised up after late returns due to summer vacations. But it isn't rolling over, and it is unsustainably fast. https://t.co/6AS9uek7N7

Just a reminder that Fed policy is contingent on the data, whatever their dots say. I don't know for sure what the data will do; neither do they; and neither do you. Stop looking for certainty. There isn't any.

3/3: …Full mean reversion in dealer margins would be a huge downward force on core inflation. The next few months' headline could easily be "look how fast inflation is falling!" Back to the 70s? Nope.

2/3: …starving retail dealers of inventory. So they passed on the auction price increases and added *a lot* of extra margin on top. That could never be sustained; even a modest increase in inventory is enough to start the reversal. How far, how fast? Unknowable, but…

1/3: The March Core CPI undershot consensus mostly because used auto prices fell by 3.8%, far more than implied by the lagged auction price data. Why? Because dealer margins are re-compressing after rocketing last year, when rental fleets bought tons of cars…

5.  But ADP has overstated the initial payroll print by more than 450K three times in the past year. It's hopelessly unreliable.

4. A soft payroll print is also signalled by drops in the NFIB hiring intentions measure and the ISM services index. In fact, everything but the ADP reading earlier this week suggests that the payroll consensus is too high.

3. I could easily be blindsided by a bigger-than-usual gap between the HB/UKG/ASA data and the official unadjusted payroll numbers, and/or the seasonal factor. But then again, so could the consensus, in the opposite direction.

2. In March, Homebase is consistent with a small fall in payrolls, while UKG and ASA signal small increases. I put more weight on Homebase, so the forecast is zero. But this is a deeply imprecise art in the Covid era, and the margin of error is maybe +/-350K.

...ADP almost always *overstates* the official numbers, because mean reversion is interrupted by the weather hit. Is the Covid third wave analogous to a weather hit? Homebase data say yes, so my guess is that payrolls will disappoint this morning. End.

3. ADP is generated by a model which includes *last month's* official payroll numbers. Usually that's not a problem, because mean reversion is powerful in payrolls, *unless* there's a shock, like a winter storm, or a hurricane. Under those conditions...

2. Homebase employment data point in the other direction, and are consistent with private payrolls up only about 150K.  Why might ADP overstate this month after so many understatements? Because it's bad at capturing sudden shifts in the trend…

1. The payroll number this morning is a bit of a wild card. ADP said 307K private jobs, but it has undershot the official number *every* month since Covid struck. Applying the average error for the past three month generates 730K. Great! But...
